evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew withstands alternative interpretations or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew interactions, and operational context within the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observable and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, specifically in the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands alternative explanations and contradicting evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in the pushback phase of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, as captured in the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early data segment.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.

assumptions: Communication attempts imply coordination efforts; the incident outcome implies breakdown despite these efforts.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication preventing the incident or no observable coordination issues, the claim would be weakened.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, supporting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown as the pushback was stopped and taken over. H4-H5 document the incident outcome consistent with breakdown effects.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether communication was fully effective or breakdown was partial; no explicit statement of communication failure.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observable and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, specifically in the hist_dynamic_und_t1_early dataset.

assumptions: Ground markings (TRP) are assumed to be adequate and visible as no contrary evidence is provided.
No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence indicates equipment faults.
Communication between crew and tug operators was effective based on provided evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings were inadequate or obscured, or if mechanical faults were documented, the conclusion might shift.
If communication breakdown evidence indicated miscoordination causing the deviation, the attribution to procedural deviation would weaken.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation by showing the aircraft moved beyond the designated stop point (TRP) and hit a barrier, indicating a deviation in pushback execution. H5 confirms the tug instructor's corrective action, supporting the observation of the deviation. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over environmental or mechanical causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on environmental marking adequacy or mechanical system status; communication appears intact but not fully detailed.
